Name: Mrs. Joe Telfer
Address: Saskatoon, Sask.
Birthplace: Port Seton, Scotland

1. Introductory Questions
   What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1912
   Where did you set up housekeeping? Saskatoon
   Where had you been living before that? Scotland
   For how many people did you prepare meals? Two
   How far was it to your nearest store? Ten miles
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
   Flour, tea, sugar, lard, salt, and essentials

2. Flour and Other Grain Products
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Mott's
   In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs.
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? £2.75
   How much did you use Graham flour?
   Whole wheat flour?
   Was flour milled locally? No
   How far away? ....... what year? .......
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? £6.4
   What other grain products did you use? Rye
   Cornmeal? .............. Whole wheat? .............. Farina? yes
   Other? .............................................................
   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
   How did you grind it? By barn mill
1. **PERSONAL HISTORY**

   - **Year:** All you start working? In Eastern Canada? 1912.
   - **Where did you go to school?** Puddicombewood.
   - **How far have you been living before that?** Westward.
   - **For how many people did you work regularly?** Two.
   - **How far can I go to your nearest store?** Near Canada.
   - **Have you visited the store recently?** Yes.

2. **FOOD AND NUTRITION**

   - **What brand of butter do you use in the early morning?** No.
   - **In what quantities did you buy last week?** 1 lb.
   - **What was the usual price per pound of white flour?** $2.75.
   - **How much did you use?** 4 lbs.
   - **What kind of flour?** No.
   - **Was flour milled locally?** No.
   - **What was the price for a twenty-pound bag of flour?** $6.4.
   - **Did you purchase any other products?** Yes.
   - **Cornmeal?** No.
   - **Sugar?** Yes.
   - **Did you buy any other food?** Yes.

3. **TOTAL EXPENSES**

   - **Total your expenses for last week:** $10.
3. SUGAR AND SYRUP

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 80 cents.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Rodgers.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 1 lb. pack.

At what price? 90 cents.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Cow.

Butter? Made from eggs? Skimmed cream.

What was the price of butter? 25 cents/lb.

Did you purchase eggs for butter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Did you make cheese? Yes.

What kind of cheese?

What was your meat supply in the early years? Wild meat.

How did you get fresh meat? Bought.

How often did you get fresh meat?

How did you preserve meat? Canned.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so, what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? All kinds.

For how long? Eight years.

What part did fish play in the family diet?

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned?

Kinds?

6. **BUYING**
   - What kind of tea did you buy? **Black tea**.
   - What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) **Ground coffee**.
   - Other beverages? **None**.

7. **VEGETABLES**
   - What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you got them from the store? **$1.50**.
   - Could you get potatoes at the store? **Yes**.
   - If not, where from? **From Prince Albert, November 1918**.
   - What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of? **1918**.
   - Potatoes **Carrots**.
   - Turnips **Beets**.
   - In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? **5 lbs**.
   - How did you buy prunes? (in bulk or by the box)? **By the box**.
   - What weights? **5 lbs**.
   - How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? **Loosely**.
   - What was the price of prunes? **12 cents**.
   - What was the price of carrots? **12 cents**.
   - What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, prunes, currants, raisins, sultanas, etc.)?

8. **PRESERVATION**
   - In what area of the country did you preserve any foods by air-drying? **Saskatchewan**.
   - What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? **1918**.
   - Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? **Yes**.
   - To what extent? **Yes**.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at that time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast - rolled oat porridge, toast, tea, milk
Dinner - soup, potatoes, eggs
Supper - potatoes, eggs, jam, tea
Family of four - same menu winter and summer

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada? ...1920........ Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

menu: roast chicken, potatoes, carrots, cranberry sauce, pie, cake.
Guests: old timers, Cecil Way, Charlie Kruger

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Only had - bread - milk - potatoes - butter - eggs.
17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. Do in the approximate month, etc., order.

Breakfast - rolled oats porridge, bacon, toast, milk

Dinner - roast potatoes, eggs, jam, tea

Supper - potato pie, tea

Family four - name names, events, and summer

18. What will you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada? Appreciate it now at that time.

menu: roast chicken, potatoes, carrots, cranberry pudding

Yours, old friend, Beulah Way, Eldon Hunger

19. Have you ever refused to allow a stranger to enter your home? Locally produced foods? Are they still available?

Only have - travel - milk - potatoes bulky $80
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

buy meat and fish - fruit

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Still use home grown as much as possible

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

In early years coal oil was bought from Prince Albert. After what was grown, it was taken to Prince Albert and milled for flour.
20. Mention any substantial difference in the preparation of meals in the early years compared to today.

Still use hominy grits as much as possible.

21. When did you begin to rely on prepared foods and processed foods instead of homemade and fresh prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

In early years corn oil was bought from Pennsylvania. After wheat was grown, it was taken to Pennsylvania and milled for flour.
